etymology.description: Pictogram: a snake; later borrowed for 蟲/虫 (worms, insects). Traditional 蟲: ideogrammic compound, triplication of 虫.
etymology.interpretation: Originally depicting a snake, the graph was later repurposed to write ‘insect/bug/worm’, while the traditional form 蟲 triples 虫 to suggest many small crawlies. The original snake sense was reassigned to 虺.
etymology.simplification: Borrowing and stroke reduction: simplified Chinese replaced 蟲 with the older, simpler 虫 to reduce strokes and standardize usage; the snake meaning moved to 虺.

examples.chinese: 这只虫在叶子上爬(這隻蟲在葉子上爬)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè zhī chóng zài yèzi shàng pá.
examples.english: This bug is crawling on a leaf.

examples.chinese: 夏天蚊虫很多(夏天蚊蟲很多)。
examples.english: There are many mosquitoes and insects in summer.
